abstract.p: Nate Chinen reviews latest CD by Karrin Allyson; photo (S)

block.p: Vocalese, the practice of retrofitting instrumental songs and solos with original lyrics, has long been a standard tool in the arsenal of a certain kind of jazz singer. Jon Hendricks popularized it in the 1950's and 60's; Kurt Elling embodies its contemporary incarnation. ''Footprints'' is not Karrin Allyson's vocalese album, strictly speaking -- the lyrics, mainly by Chris Caswell, are affixed only to melodies, not solos -- but it celebrates that entire tradition, including the unavoidably corny parts.

Vocalese, the practice of retrofitting instrumental songs and solos with original lyrics, has long been a standard tool in the arsenal of a certain kind of jazz singer. Jon Hendricks popularized it in the 1950's and 60's; Kurt Elling embodies its contemporary incarnation. ''Footprints'' is not Karrin Allyson's vocalese album, strictly speaking -- the lyrics, mainly by Chris Caswell, are affixed only to melodies, not solos -- but it celebrates that entire tradition, including the unavoidably corny parts.

Ms. Allyson welcomes Mr. Hendricks on a pair of his inventions, and performs another pair by the singer Oscar Brown Jr., who died last year. She also features the West Coast veteran Nancy King as a duo partner, most effectively in a take on Nat Adderley's ''Never Say Yes.'' That piece -- like ''Teaneck'' and ''Unit 7,'' both additional highlights -- was a nonvocal interlude on the classic album ''Nancy Wilson & Cannonball Adderley.'' Ms. Allyson and Mr. Caswell deserve credit for providing those texts with such loving annotations.
